text: london reuters a child born today faces multiple and life long health harms from climate change growing up in a warmer world with risks of food shortages infectious diseases floods and extreme heat a major global study has found
label: media

text: climate change is already harming people s health by increasing the number of extreme weather events and exacerbating air pollution according to the study published in the lancet medical journal
label: media

text: and if nothing is done to mitigate it its impacts could burden an entire generation with disease and illness throughout their lives
label: media

text: children are particularly vulnerable to the health risks of a changing climate
label: media

text: their bodies and immune systems are still developing leaving them more susceptible to disease and environmental pollutants said nick watts who co led the lancet countdown on health and climate change study
label: media

text: he warned that health damage in early childhood is persistent and pervasive and carries lifelong consequences
label: media

text: without immediate action from all countries to cut greenhouse gas emissions gains in wellbeing and life expectancy will be compromised and climate change will come to define the health of an entire generation he told a london briefing
label: media

text: yet introducing policies to limit emissions and cap global warming would see a different outcome the research teams said
label: media

text: in that scenario a child born today would see an end to coal use in britain for example by their 6th birthday and the world reaching net zero emissions by the time they were 31
label: media

label: media

text: on a business as usual pathway with little action to limit climate change it found that amid rising temperatures and extreme weather events children would be vulnerable to malnutrition and rising food prices and the most likely to suffer from warmer waters and climates accelerating the spread of infectious diseases such as dengue fever and cholera

text: advertisement one of the main items on the cop26 agenda is aiming for a global reduction in fossil fuel burning
label: media

text: fossil fuels are formed from the fossilised remains of dead plants and animals that humans extract and burn for their carbon containing energy content
label: media

text: they include coal crude oil and natural gas
label: media

text: burning fossil fuels has been shown to have direct adverse effects on our health
label: media

text: air pollution continues to be a serious public health concern affecting nine out of 10 individuals living in urban areas worldwide
label: media

text: exposure to air pollution is the ninth biggest risk factor for lung and heart damage
label: media

text: burning coal is a leading cause of greenhouse gas emissions as well as an array of toxic chemicals
label: media

text: china india and the united states are the world s main coal mining regions
label: media

text: however indonesia australia russia south africa and colombia also produce large amounts
label: media

text: coal burning not only releases carbon dioxide and methane two of the worst greenhouse gases but also sulphur dioxide nitrogen oxide and mercury all of which are harmful to human health
label: media

text: crude oil combustion also releases harmful gases such as carbon dioxide and sulphur into the atmosphere whereas burning natural gas can release the powerful greenhouse gas methane when it is heated and compressed to release energy into the air
label: media

text: the lungs are the primary organ affected by gases and chemicals released by fossil fuel burning
label: media

text: people who work in coal mines are far more likely to suffer from lung diseases like emphysema and bronchitis both conditions obstruct airways and make it difficult to breathe
label: media

text: those who live near coal stations and breathe in air that contains the harmful components that coal burning releases are also at higher risk of suffering from these conditions
label: media

text: it is time for change we must demand better from our leaders and no longer sleepwalk alongside them into climate catastrophe
label: media

text: nitrogen oxide in particular can affect the protein component in the lungs and reduce their ability to inflate and deflate as well as they should meaning airflow is reduced leaving people with chronic lung conditions that can leave them short of breath
label: media

text: inhalation of these same chemicals has also been shown to have an adverse effect on the heart muscle in some people causing it to become bigger and weaker a condition known as cardiac muscle hypertrophy
label: media

label: media

text: studies have shown that children exposed to higher levels of carbon in the air have an increased risk of cognitive impairment and even memory issues
label: media

label: media

text: and it is not just women being affected there has been a steady decline in overall sperm count in men over the last 50 years with poor air quality thought to play a factor

text: air pollution has also been linked to lower birthweights in newborn babies as well as an increased risk of premature delivery which in itself carries a high risk of health complications for babies
label: media

label: media

text: personal account should the uk be removing countries from its red list
label: media

text: on the morning of november 1 2021 the uk officially removed any remaining countries from its red list
label: media

text: this meant travellers returning from ecuador the dominican republic colombia peru panama haiti and venezuela will no longer have to quarantine in hotels
label: media

text: those arriving fully vaccinated or below 18 years of age do not need to complete a predeparture covid test a test on the eighth day after arriving or isolate for 10 days at home
label: media

text: with covid cases in the uk so high in comparison to many of our neighbouring countries we are likely to be exporting more coronavirus than we are importing but i remain concerned about our lax borders
label: media

text: advertisement i fully empathise with the hardships the travel industry has had to endure during this pandemic
label: media

text: it has been affected more than most but speaking as a doctor i remain concerned about the lack of reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction rt pcr testing for people returning to the uk
label: media

text: those who return from trips abroad or visit us here provided they are fully vaccinated need only do a lateral flow test on the second day after arrival
label: media

text: this then means they have to self report the result to a government website
label: media

text: the onus is on the individual to report the correct result there are no checks in place to see if tests are actually being done or if the result being reported is indeed the true reading
label: media

text: i would like to think that most people will report their results honestly and book a rt pcr test and isolate should their lateral flow test come back positive but i know this will not be the case for everyone
label: media

text: my other concern is that the lack of routine rt pcr testing for people arriving from overseas means we have less of a handle on any new variants that might inadvertently be imported in
label: media

text: we saw what happened when the delta variant was allowed in through open borders earlier this year
label: media

text: my advice would have been to have kept the day 2 rt pcr testing in place rather than replace it with a self reported lateral flow test
label: media

text: that way we could support the travel industry while keeping a closer eye on what was coming in through our borders
label: media

text: only time will tell if the uk government s current policy is the correct one
label: media

text: advertisement reader s question what is the valneva covid vaccine
label: media

text: the valneva vaccine made by french company valneva is a proposed covid 19 vaccine that is yet to complete trials
label: media

text: the vaccine technology is more traditional in that it uses a similar technique to polio and flu vaccines relying on an inactivated whole version of the coronavirus which cannot replicate or cause disease
label: media

text: after being inactivated the virus is purified and combined with an adjuvant that helps stimulate an immune response
label: media

text: the reason why there is such interest in this vaccine is that instead of just relying on the spike protein part of the virus as the pfizer moderna and astrazeneca vaccines do this one presents the whole virus to the immune system meaning that in theory you get an immune response to the whole virus and not just part of it
label: media

text: this means that if a part of the actual coronavirus mutates in the future as we have seen with emerging variants your immune system will still recognise the unmutated parts and neutralise it
label: media

text: the hope is that vaccines using this technology will be able to provide protection for longer rather than needing to be reformulated to get ahead of new variants
label: media

text: the results from trials so far have been promising with good immune responses reported as well as no serious adverse effects
label: media

text: phase three trials are ongoing but the uk has already ordered 100 million doses and countries like australia have also expressed an interest
label: media

text: if we have a vaccine that gets us ahead of any future variants that may emerge it will indeed be a game changer
label: media
